text: Hi! I have a function, let's say `f(ϕ) = sin(ϕ), ϕ = 0...10`. Now I want to break that function down in a list of lines that approximates the real function well (maybe with a maximum or minimum line length, angle between lines, or number of lines). Is there a package that can help with that? Bonus points if it also works in polar coordinates.

text: Oh I see. Number pairs in cartesian/polar coordinates that get connected to lines. Close to zero `sin` is almost `identity`  so the first line might be (0.0, 0.0) -> (0.1, 0.1). Second line might be (0.1, 0.1) -> (0.2, 0.198), but now this one will be a bit shorter.

text: I don't understand what you mean by Polar Coordinates. It seems like you wish to use linear functions to approximate functions. Around a point, just take the first derivative and take the tangent. With a bunch a points, its a little trickier.

elements.text: I don't understand what you mean by Polar Coordinates. It seems like you wish to use linear functions to approximate functions. Around a point, just take the first derivative and take the tangent. With a bunch a points, its a little trickier.

text: well, linear interpolation of the output of your function is the easiest route - maximum/minimum line length or angle is trickier

elements.text: well, linear interpolation of the output of your function is the easiest route - maximum/minimum line length or angle is trickier

text: the "number of lines" part is basically the size of your input space divided by the step size

elements.text: the "number of lines" part is basically the size of your input space divided by the step size

text: Yes, the "number of lines" part only really makes sense in combination with something else, so N lines but non longer/shorter than ... .

elements.text: Yes, the "number of lines" part only really makes sense in combination with something else, so N lines but non longer/shorter than ... .

text: for the maximum/minimum line length, I guess you could take a default step forward and if the resulting line is too long, just take a half-step backward? it's not really suited to e.g. something like the weierstrass function though

elements.text: for the maximum/minimum line length, I guess you could take a default step forward and if the resulting line is too long, just take a half-step backward? it's not really suited to e.g. something like the weierstrass function though

text: I don't think you can guarantee a maximum linelength combined with exactly N lines in the general case for any input range and function though :thinking_face:

elements.text: I don't think you can guarantee a maximum linelength combined with exactly N lines in the general case for any input range and function though

text:
I'm just going to work with basic linear/trigonometric functions and I wouldn't worry about the corner cases yet. I do want to end up at the end, otherwise I'm going to have some overlap.
I have some idea how to do it, for line length you could look at the line integral, for maximum angle at the derivative... I thought there might be some package that does this since I think you do something similar with adaptive algorithms when integrating/differentiating.

elements.text:
I'm just going to work with basic linear/trigonometric functions and I wouldn't worry about the corner cases yet. I do want to end up at the end, otherwise I'm going to have some overlap.
I have some idea how to do it, for line length you could look at the line integral, for maximum angle at the derivative... I thought there might be some package that does this since I think you do something similar with adaptive algorithms when integrating/differentiating.

text: my intuition tells me that you'll only be able to end up on the end of the range AND guarantee maximum/minimum line length if the second derivative of your function is constant

elements.text: my intuition tells me that you'll only be able to end up on the end of the range AND guarantee maximum/minimum line length if the second derivative of your function is constant

text: well, cranking up the number of lines could help, but that may overshoot as well if you don't allow it to be only an upperbound

elements.text: well, cranking up the number of lines could help, but that may overshoot as well if you don't allow it to be only an upperbound

text: Hey <@UCB7L9W49>, if you were able to find an answer here on Slack, please cross post it to Discourse via the link above. Thank you!

You can use Interpolations.jl for this.

Just generate some data from the function:
```using Interpolations

ϕdata = 0.:0.1:10.
fdata = sin.(ϕdata)

it = LinearInterpolation(ϕdata, fdata, extrapolation_bc = Flat())```

elements.text:
You can use Interpolations.jl for this.

Just generate some data from the function:

using Interpolations

ϕdata = 0.:0.1:10.
fdata = sin.(ϕdata)

it = LinearInterpolation(ϕdata, fdata, extrapolation_bc = Flat())
